title: B force on charges - 2 plates - 2 B-field regions

Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows two regions of uniform magnetic field <math alttext="vector B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="vector B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is out of the plane of the figure in both regions, on either side of two charged parallel plates. The left plate has a positive charge, the right plate has a negative charge of equal magnitude, and there is a uniform electric field between the plates. Each plate’s charge is distributed uniformly over each plate. In the center of each plate is a small hole that does not significantly affect the uniformity of the electric field. Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> is located halfway between the centers of the plates. A potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> exists between the plates, which are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>.

A small particle of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and positive charge <math alttext="positive q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></math> is released from rest at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, passes through the hole in one of the plates, and continues moving into one of the magnetic field regions. Gravitational forces exerted on the particle are negligible.

(a) On Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, draw the path of the particle starting at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and ending either where it exits one of the magnetic field regions or stops moving upon colliding with one of the plates.

A small particle of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and positive charge <math alttext="positive q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></math> is released from rest at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, passes through the hole in one of the plates, and continues moving into one of the magnetic field regions. (a) On Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, draw the path of the particle starting at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and ending either where it exits one of the magnetic field regions or stops moving upon colliding with one of the plates.

(b) Express your answers to the following in terms of <math alttext="vector B sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math> and physical constants, as appropriate.

i. Derive an expression for the speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> of the particle at the instant it reaches the hole in one of the plates.
ii. Derive an expression for the radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> of the path that the particle follows while in one of the magnetic field regions.

(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> of the particle as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. Time <math alttext="t sub P" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></msub></math> is the instant that the particle is released at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, and <math alttext="t sub H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub></math> is the instant that the particle reaches the hole in one of the plates. Assume that the particle does not stop or leave the magnetic field region during the time interval shown on the time axis of the graph. On the vertical axis, label any maxima or minima for <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> in terms of given quantities and physical constants, as appropriate.

Note: if a minimum is zero, you do NOT need to add a label for it.

The charge on each plate is now reduced, with the charges on the two plates still equal in magnitude and uniformly distributed on the respective plates. A second particle, with the same mass and charge as the original particle, is released from rest at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.

(d) Describe how the path of the second particle in the magnetic field region differs from that of the original particle, if at all. If the two particles’ paths are the same, indicate that explicitly. Justify your answer using the expression you derived in part (b)(ii).
